subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized Test Case example
msgSnippet: ... To my mind, this approach is more explicit than the parameterized test case example.  That is, I prefer the level of test language used here over the
messageBody:
On Nov 20, 2003, at 3:02 PM, Lasitha Ranatunga wrote:

> I've been solving this kind of duplication by creating my own
> assertions.
> As an example, see my version of CalculateAgeTest below. I'm curious
> about
> the pros/cons of each approach?
>
> cheers, lasitha.
>
> ----------------
> package ca.bluejays.scouting.amateur.model.test;
>
> import java.util.Date;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import XXX.BiographicalReport;
> import XXX.PlayerFactory;
>
> import com.diasparsoftware.java.util.DateUtil;
>
> public class CalculateAgeTest2 extends TestCase {
>
> public void testBirthday() {
> assertCorrectAge(30, DateUtil.makeDate(2004, 5, 4));
> }
>
> public void testDayBeforeBirthday() {
> assertCorrectAge(29, DateUtil.makeDate(2004, 5, 3));
> }
>
> public void testDayAfterBirthday() {
> assertCorrectAge(30, DateUtil.makeDate(2004, 5, 5));
> }
>
> public void testDateOfBirth() {
> assertCorrectAge(0, DateUtil.makeDate(1974, 5, 4));
> }
>
> public void testInvalidFutureDate() {
> assertCorrectAge(0, DateUtil.makeDate(1974, 5, 3));
> }
>
> private void assertCorrectAge(int expectedAge, Date futureDate) {
> BiographicalReport biographicalReport = PlayerFactory
> .makeBiographicalReport("Joe", "Rainsberger", DateUtil
> .makeDate(1974, 5, 4));
>
> assertEquals(new Integer(expectedAge),
> biographicalReport.getAgeAsOf(futureDate));
> }
> }


To my mind, this approach is more explicit than the parameterized test
case example. That is, I prefer the level of test language used here
over the language used to coerce JUnit to do it for me. But that's
just my mind...

Mike
